utterances: That's right.
At about the same time, Republicans were definitely taking more blame.
We've just been hearing about the looming debt ceiling and you asked people about that.
And you found, to cite a headline from your poll, 4 in 10 say the government can go past debt limit.
You mean to just blow through it?
Well, they think we can go past the deadline without major problems.
But 47 percent, a few more, say that it is essential to deal with this debt fix before the deadline to avoid a crisis in our economy.
This was similar to something we saw in 2011 going into the debt ceiling.
For a lot of Americans, this is a very opaque issue and it's hard to understand the implications of it.
Here's a discouraging answer.
You asked people, first, should President Obama change health care to achieve a deal?
And also, should Republicans drop their demands for health care changes for deal?
And those two questions polled about the same number of yeses, in the 40s, but both short of a majority.
Yes, right.
The same thing that's locking up Congress is dividing the public.
Who should give ground on the issue of attaching health care to a budget deal?
Forty-two percent say Obama should give ground.
Forty-four percent say Republicans should give ground.
And there's very little room to compromise in the political bases.
Most Democrats say it would be unacceptable for Obama to back down on this.
But most Republicans say it would be unacceptable for their party leaders to back down on this.
And that's where we are right now.
You're saying, in effect, this logjam didn't descend upon us from heaven.
This is a conflict in our society, as well.
It is a conflict in society.
The source is unclear.
I mean, they may be hearing what their political leaders are saying.
But their political leaders are certainly also hearing what they're saying.
You asked a question about the Tea Party.
Are Republican leaders paying too much attention to them?
Most Democrats say yes.
But I was surprised at how few Republicans do.
Only, I think, 18 percent said they're paying too much attention to the Tea Party.
Yeah, that's right.
We've been hearing a lot in coverage of Capitol Hill and from political leaders in Washington about concerns in the Republican Party that the Tea Party is holding too much sway.
Well, in the general Republican electorate nationwide, that's not that widespread a concern.
Only 18 percent of Republicans think the Tea Party is getting too much attention from leadership.
Forty percent think it's right and 24 percent still say there's too little attention to the Tea Party.
Even Republicans who themselves don't agree with the Tea Party don't really express a lot of concern about too much Tea Party influence.
What do you make of the answers you got when you asked people if they're being personally affected by the government shutdown?
Hi, Neal, welcome to New Hampshire, and thank you, New Hampshire Public Radio.
Trivia question is: Who was the last sitting president to be defeated in the New Hampshire primary?
If you think you know the answer to this week's trivia question, the last sitting president to be...
Well, not really out of the trunk of my car, but I was selling weed at, you know, at that point.
Those were my - that's how, you know, dilapidated my mind was.
You know, what your mindset, you know.
It's just how progressively things, you know, can be, you know, can progress.
But it was, you know, I was dealing with the, you know, some of the same struggles that a lot of people deal with.
Substance abuse, alcohol, marijuana, you know, obviously being in an NFL lifestyle, women and, you know, whatever else is at your grip.
And, you know, when I got the fines, you know, basically, my mindset was, hey, man I got some good bud.
I've got some good marijuana, might as well start selling it.
And, you know, it's just - it's amazing how gripped you can become, you know.
And people like to think that, you know, the music or, you know, the things that are, you know, out there in our society don't have impact on people, but they do, you know.
My thing was, it was a keep it real generation, and that's as real as it gets.
You know, you want to be a gangster, let's stop playing and, you know.
Is that what happens to so many young athletes, particularly black ones, who keep getting in trouble with the law, even though they have all this money in their pockets?

Well, you realize that - I found, this is my personal experience, you know, if you don't have the right understanding, you know, the wisdom and the know how to understand what the money's used for, I believe it intensifies every dark part of your life.
Whereas, you know, I liked women obviously.
Now I attract more women.
You know, I got drugs, now I can afford the drugs that I - whereas I couldn't afford them before.
So that's exactly what money did for me, and that's why he said the love of money is the root of all evil.
You don't have the right understanding of the means of it, it goes usually to the wrong places.
Tell me about the epiphany that you had.
Yeah.
I would say that those are my struggles and I get to that point where, you know, I'm selling these drugs with friends as well.

I get pulled over with half a pound of marijuana, and while I'm in that jail cell - first time in my life where I sincerely cried out, the guy who wasn't raising in a Christian home at all, he didn't even do church on Easter, all the drug dealers in church on Easter, you know.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But, you know, I'm in that jail cell and I just say God, all I know is I need you right now, and if you don't mind I would appreciate it if I can keep my job as well.
And, you know, like I said, I was in real prayer.

And within that time span from, you know, for about 11 days, God literally deliver me with no lasting effects from alcohol, drugs, never slept with other women other than my wife, and 11 days later I walk into a church where, you know, I probably wept in back of the church for about 20 minutes as I saw this woman singing to God.
I saw that she had peace.
I saw she had joy.
She was singing to God, and I realized that, you know, there's 80 percent of men of my age which would trade places with me in a heartbeat, but I didn't have that.
And so I wept and I gave it all God, gave it to Christ, and my life's never been the same.
A lot of people are talking about black fathers these days, because of Barack Obama's Father's Day speech and there's been a lot of controversy.
You're a father, you grew up without a father, as I understand it.
No, I actually had a very good father, we just - he just divorced - my parents were divorced.

He was very close, you know, always around, but you know that still has a lasting effect, which kind of raises a certain level of bitterness that, you know thanks to my relationship with Christ I learned to be free from.

You know, there's different levels, you know, so many people grow up fatherless, or, you know especially, obviously in black homes, or, you know, in minority homes they grow up, you know, in single parent homes.
And, you know, it raises a level of a mindset of destruction where it was never intended to be that way.
And you know, so a man doesn't - there's only certain things that a mother can do for you.
You know, certain things that you need, you know, that you need from your father.
You know, even - especially as a male, but even as a female.
A father, you know, his job is to show, you know, his daughter what she can expect.
Now, you're a father now, you've got twins this year.
Yes, I just had identical twin girls.
Congratulations on that.
So my job is, you know, is twofold, you know.

You know, obviously, to show my men what it is, you know, show my boys what it is, to, you know, foster them, and be obviously number one God-fearing, but, you know, love, respect, you know, all those virtues that we need you know raise our children in, but to show my - to show my daughters as well what they need to expect, you know, from a man.
You know, so that they're not slighted, you know, as they grow up.
Let's end this with talking about football.
If you had dropped that ball?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Would you still have a book?
And what would the name of this book be?
Oh man.
If I dropped it, I would like to think I still have a story that's definitely worth telling.
You know, who knows when or where God will open that door, I don't know.
The name of it might be, you know just simply ""Broken Hearted.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Now, your number 85 jersey is up there, you know.
You only had four catches all of last year, one of them - one of the greatest catches, and maybe you'll win the Espy, we hope you do, it was a great catch.
Put us in that moment, we've got about - a little less than a minute - put us in that moment.
Here's the ball coming...
Yeah, the ball's coming.
Obviously the circumstances, you know, maybe a minute left, less than a minute.
Eli, you know, that's the first half of the miracle, is him getting away from three Patriot defenders.
Ball's in the air, you just do your best to position yourself.
High-point it, go up, I feel the heat from Rodney Harrison, my Siamese twin for a little bit, and you know, I didn't know anything.
I'd be lying if I told you I knew I had that thing on my helmet.
But the only thing in my heart I'm saying, I ain't letting this ball go at all.
Man, it was a great catch, and it was something I'm sure you will remember for the rest of your career.
Rodney Harrison said you would never make that catch again in 10,000 tries.
(Reading) Dear Santa, thanks for the tree.
We left you cookies, but Harry ate them.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah, you know, I hope his heart was right.
I would be the first one to agree, but I hope his heart was right when he was saying it because, you know, I'm not taking credit for the catch.
I'm giving it all to God, you know, and that's the biggest difference.
And, you know, I think he was a part - he was just an instrument as well.
I think he did everything in his natural abilityâ€¦
To make that play.
David Tyree, great having you, thank you very much.
Had a great time, thanks for having me.
That was NPR's Tony Cox speaking with David Tyree.
Tyree, plays for the New York Giants, and has a forthcoming book called ""More Than Just the Catch,"" which will be on shelves in September.
He joined us here in our studios at NPR West in Culver City.
To check out the video of our interview with David Tyree, go to nprnewsandviews.org
And now we turn to Nigeria, where millions voted today in an election marked by dramatic twists.
At the last minute, the vote was delayed a week because of logistical challenges, infuriating many people.
But across the country, voters formed long lines outside polling stations under the scorching sun for a generally peaceful election.
However, violent incidents were reported in several cities with explosions in the northeastern part of the country where an insurgency continues.
NPR's Ofeibea Quist-Arcton is in the capital Abuja, and she's with us now.
Ofeibea, thanks so much for joining us.
Greetings.
So at last, Nigerians have voted, albeit a week late.
You watched the vote unfold.
Tell us what the voters have been telling you.
Voters were saying, oh, at last we're here.
Listen, for example, to Ruka Ajana.
She said that she was ready to vote a week ago, but she was determined to vote today because voting is so important.
Listen to what she says are the priorities.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
